Functions#

Metrics on states or operators#

Adj#

Adj(A)#

This function calculates the hermitian conjugate of a quantum object.

Parameters:

A (DiracObject) – Openket expression, this could be a Bra, Ket, Operator or complex number.

Returns:

The hermitian conjugate of A.

Return type:

DiracObject

Examples#

>>> Adj(1 + I)
1-I

>>> Adj(Ket(0))
<0|
>>> Adj(Bra(1))
|1>

Of course, it’s all possible to calculate the norm of any state.

>>> w = I*Ket(0) - 4*Ket(1)
>>> w
I|0> - 4|1>
>>> norm = Adj(w)*w
>>> norm
17

Normalize#

Normalize(state)#

This function produces a vector in a Hilbert space with norm equal to unity.

Parameters:

state (DiracObject) – Total expression of vector(s) or a quantum state.

Returns:

The normalized corresponding state.

Return type:

DiracObject

Commutator#

Commutator(A, B)#

This function calculates the conmutator of two operators.

Parameters:

  • A (Operator) – The operator or matrix.

  • B (Operator) – The operator or matrix.

Returns:

The conmutator of A and B.

Return type:

Operator

TraceOut#

TraceOut(A, htag)#

This function computes the partial trace of a series of outer products or a bipartite density matrix.

Parameters:

  • A (Linear combination of KetBra objects) – Bipartite density matrix or total expression of outer products.

  • htag (string) – Tag of the Hilbert space you will be tracing out.

Returns:

The partial trace of A acting only in htag space.

Return type:

Linear combination of KetBra objects

Example#

>>> psi = Ket(0,"A")*Ket(1,"B") - Ket(1,"A")*Ket(0,"B")
>>> psi
|0_A>|1_B> - |1_A>|0_B>
>>> R = psi*Adj(psi)
>>> R
|0_A>|1_B><1_B|<0_A| - |0_A>|1_B><0_B|<1_A| - |1_A>|0_B><1_B|<0_A| + |1_A>|0_B><0_B|<1_A|
>>>
>>>
>>> RB = TraceOut(R,"A")
>>> RB
|0_B><0_B| + |1_B><1_B|
>>> RA = TraceOut(R,"B")
>>> RA
|0_A><0_A| + |1_A><1_A|

Trace#

Trace(A, basis='default')#

This function computes the total trace of a sum of exterior products or density matrix. It finds the total number of Hilbert spaces and their tags and then it uses TraceOut over all of them succesively, returning a complex number.

Parameters:

  • A (Linear combination of KetBra objects) – Bipartite density matrix or total expression of outer products.

  • basis

Returns:

The total trace of A acting in all Hilbert spaces.

Return type:

number

Example#

Continuing with the previus example:

>>> Trace(R)
2

Visualization#

Qmatrix#

Qmatrix(A, basis='default')#

This function returns the matrix representation of any operator.

Parameters:

  • A (Linear combination of KetBra objects) – Sum of outer products.

  • basis (list, optional) – List of Ket objects that conforms the basis in which the matrix will be represented. If no basis is specified, the function founds out how many different kets or bras the expression (sum of the outer products) contains, to determine the basis and the size of the matrix. For the moment, these can only be eigenvectors of a single operator.

Raises:

Exception – Raised if exterior products are expressed in differents Hilbert spaces.

Returns:

The matrix representation of A in basis or a default basis.

Return type:

Sympy Matrix

Time evolution#

Dictionary#

Dictionary(A, basis)#

This function creates a dictionary object with keys as \(\langle i|\rho|j \rangle\) objects in a given basis and their definitions as values. The function creates variables representing a complex number, e.g. a+ib, where a and b are defined as real variables. If the basis used has \(n\) elements, \(n^2\) variables are created. It is assumed that all variables are complex and the definition of each \(\langle i|\rho|j \rangle\) are the variables themselves.

Parameters:

  • A (Operator) – The operator involved.

  • basis (list of Ket) – List of Ket objects containing all the elements of the basis.

Returns:

Dictionary object whose keys correspond to \(\langle i|\) A \(|j \rangle\) objects in the basis basis, and the values to their corresponding defition represented as variable.

Return type:

dict

Example#

>>> b = [Ket(0), Ket(1)]
>>> R = Operator("R")
>>> Dictionary(R, b)
{'<0|R|0>': I*Im0 + Re0, '<0|R|1>': I*Im1 + Re1, '<1|R|0>': I*Im2 + Re2, '<1|R|1>': I*Im3 + Re3}

Qch#

Qch(expr, dic)#

This function looks within a given expression for keys in the Dictionary dictionary, and substitutes them with their value. It discriminates coefficients and other terms which are not in the dictionary, leaving them the same.

Parameters:

  • expr (Lineal combination of BraOperatorKet objects.) – Openket expression of a sum of \(\langle i|\rho|j \rangle\) objects.

  • dic (dict) – Dictionary object given by the Dictionary function.

Returns:

The total mathematical expression of expr represented by D values.

Return type:

Mathematical expression with real variables

Example#

>>> b = [Ket(0), Ket(1)]
>>> R = Operator("R")
#{'<0|R|0>': I*Im0 + Re0, '<0|R|1>': I*Im1 + Re1, '<1|R|0>': I*Im2 + Re2, '<1|R|1>': I*Im3 + Re3}
>>> D = Dictionary(R, b)
#<0|R|0> + 2*I<0|R|1> +  - 3.4<1|R|1>
>>> expression =  Bra(0)*R*Ket(0)+2*I*Bra(0)*R*Ket(1)-3.4*Bra(1)*R*Ket(1)
>>> Qch(expr, D)
I*Im0 + Re0 + 2*I*(I*Im1 + Re1) - 3.4*I*Im3 - 3.4*Re3

Qeq#

Qeq(R, Rdot, basis, filename='func', dictname='dic', GSL=False)#

The main purpose for this function is to study time evolution of an Operator, with an expression for its time derivative, both given in a specified basis. This function creates a file called filename, which defines a function in the sintaxis needed to feed Scipy’s ODE solver odeint or GSL ODE solver.

Parameters:

  • R (Operator) – Operator involved. It should be in terms of the basis basis.

  • Rdot (Operator) – Usually the commutator of R with H, where H is the Hamiltonian of the system.

  • basis (list of Ket) – List of Ket objects containing all the elements of the basis.

  • filename (string) – The name of the out file with the function.

  • dictname (string) – The name of the dictionay file.

  • GSL (bool) – Defines the syntaxis of the ODE solver; if GLS = True define a function in the sintaxis for GSL ODE solver, if False define in the sintaxis needed to feed Scipy’s ODE solver odeint.

Returns:

Return a file with a function written in the sintaxis defined. Besides, if GLS = True also returns a file with the dictionary of the base and the variables. It first creates a dictionary with the function Dictionary, using the list basis, and the operator R, and then it finds the different expressions of time evolution for every matrix element substituting them for variables using Qch. Finally it writes the function \(f\) into a file, where the ODE has the form \(\frac{dy}{dt} = f(y,t)\); \(y\) should be understood as a vector, which is defined entry-like as a list, for example \(y[0]=x, y[1]=w\), etc., and \(t\) is the time variable. \(f\) returns also a list, containig the expressions of the derivatives of each entry of \(y\) as entries of another list. Scipy’s ODE solver odeint understands this as a collection of coupled ODE to be solved, specifying an initial condition and the time step.

Return type:

file
